summary: This is an FBI FD-302 interview report of Janusz Banasiak, a former household employee for Jeffrey Epstein, conducted on October 19, 2021. Banasiak details his hiring process, job duties, the household manual, message logs, and his awareness of the investigation into Epstein. He describes the execution of a search warrant at Epstein's Florida property and his subsequent limited interactions with Epstein.

persons.name: Janusz Banasiak
persons.role: Former household employee for Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Interviewed by the FBI about his employment with Jeffrey Epstein from 2005 to 2017. He describes his duties, the household manual, and the execution of a search warrant on Epstein's property.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the investigation. Banasiak describes working for him, his travel habits, his arrest, guilty plea, and the pay cuts he imposed on staff.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Interviewed Banasiak for the job in her New York townhouse and was a primary source of instructions on Epstein's preferences and household procedures.

persons.name: Dr. Garecki
persons.role: Person who left a phone message
persons.context: Name appears in a message log entry from February 18, 2005, that Banasiak recognized as his own handwriting.

connections.description: Banasiak was employed by Epstein from 2005 to 2017 as a household manager, driver, and groundskeeper at his Florida property.
Maxwell interviewed Banasiak for the job and was a primary conduit for instructions and information about Epstein's preferences.
Maxwell acted on Epstein's behalf in hiring staff and managing household affairs, as described by Banasiak.

events.title: Banasiak begins employment with Epstein
events.description: Janusz Banasiak is hired through an agency, interviewed by Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein, and moves to Florida to work on Epstein's property.

events.title: Documented phone message activity
events.description: Banasiak identifies numerous phone messages he logged in message books during this period, showing his role in managing communications for the household.

events.title: Execution of search warrant at Epstein's Florida property
events.description: Police arrived with a search warrant at Epstein's Florida home while Banasiak was present. He was shown the warrant, and the property was searched. Epstein was not present.

events.title: Epstein's guilty plea and incarceration
events.description: Banasiak learned from news reports that Epstein pleaded guilty to solicitation of underage prostitution and went to jail. He drove Epstein to court prior to this.

events.title: Banasiak ends employment with Epstein
events.description: Banasiak stopped working for Epstein, having lived on the property until this time.

events.title: FBI interview of Janusz Banasiak
events.description: Banasiak is interviewed by the FBI (with a U.S. Attorney and a detective present) in West Palm Beach, Florida, providing details about his employment and the investigation.

locations: New York, New York (where Banasiak lived and was interviewed by Maxwell)
Lexington Avenue and Park Avenue, New York (location of Maxwell's townhouse)
Madison Avenue, New York (location of Epstein's office)
Florida (location of Epstein's property where Banasiak worked and lived)
Palm Beach, Florida (location of court appearance)
New Mexico (mentioned as one of Epstein's travel destinations)
Paris (mentioned as one of Epstein's travel destinations)
keyFacts: Janusz Banasiak worked for Jeffrey Epstein from 2005 to 2017, living in a small house on Epstein's Florida property and performing duties as a driver, groundskeeper, and household manager.
Banasiak was interviewed and hired by Ghislaine Maxwell, who provided him with detailed instructions on Epstein's preferences and a household manual outlining procedures.
Banasiak identified his own handwriting in detailed phone message logs from 2004-2005, which were shown to him as government exhibits during the FBI interview.
Banasiak was present when law enforcement executed a search warrant on Epstein's Florida property, which is how he first learned of the investigation.
After Epstein's arrest and guilty plea, he cut employee pay by 10% and never restored it, which led Banasiak to consider leaving his job.
